report_text:
PORTS AND DEVICES: None.
        LUNGS: There is mild biapical scarring, similar to the previous
        exam. There is mild subsegmental atelectasis within the dependent
        portion of the lung bases as well as atelectasis adjacent to
        thoracic osteophytes medially within the right lower lobe.
        PULMONARY NODULES ARE AS FOLLOWS:
        1 mm nodule along the right major fissure (2:34).
        3 mm right middle lobe nodule (2:39).
        5 mm nodule medial aspect superior segment right lower lobe
        (2:40).
        5 mm left lower lobe subpleural nodule (2:51).
        5 mm left lower lobe subpleural nodule (2:59).
        2 mm right lower lobe nodule (2:58).
        1 mm left lower lobe nodule (2:66).
        Calcified granuloma left lower lobe (2:70).
        6 mm right lower lobe nodule (2:70).
        No new or enlarging pulmonary nodules.
        PLEURA: No pleural effusion.
        LYMPH NODES: No enlarged supraclavicular, axillary, mediastinal
        or hilar lymph nodes.
        MEDIASTINUM: The ascending thoracic aorta measures 3.5 x 3.7 cm
        in transverse dimension. The pulmonary arteries are ectatic. Mild
        coronary artery calcifications. No pericardial effusion.
        Chest Wall / BREASTS: Left chest wall pacing device with leads in
        the right atrium and right ventricle.
        UPPER ABDOMEN: Imaged portions of the liver and spleen are
        grossly unremarkable. The adrenal glands are normal in size and
        configuration. There is diverticular disease of the colon.
        MUSCULOSKELETAL: Mild dextroscoliosis of the thoracic spine.
        Moderate T10 compression fracture. There are multilevel
        degenerative changes of the thoracic spine.

Mild biapical scar appear similar. Mild bibasilar subsegmental
        scar or atelectasis again seen.
        PULMONARY NODULES ARE AS FOLLOWS:
        Stable 2 mm nodule along the right major fissure (35:3).
        Stable 3 mm right middle lobe nodule (42:3).
        Stable 5 mm nodule medial aspect superior segment right lower
        lobe (40:3).
        Stable 5 mm left lower lobe subpleural nodule (47:3).
        Stable 5 mm left lower lobe subpleural nodule (56:3).
        Stable 2 mm right lower lobe nodule (55:3).
        Stable 1 mm left lower lobe nodule (66:3).
        Stable calcified granuloma left lower lobe (70:3).
        Stable 6 mm right lower lobe nodule (68:3).
        No pleural effusion.
        No mediastinal lymphadenopathy. No pericardial effusion.
        Atherosclerotic calcifications in the thoracic aorta and branch
        vessels. Coronary artery calcifications. Small hiatal hernia.
        No adrenal masses.
        No axillary adenopathy.
        Moderate T10 vertebral body compression fracture again seen.
        Moderate degenerative changes in the thoracic spine. Mild
        dextroscoliosis in the thoracic spine.

There is mild biapical scarring, similar to the previous exam.
        There is mild subsegmental atelectasis within the dependent
        portion of the lung bases as well as atelectasis adjacent to
        thoracic osteophytes medially within the right lower lobe.
        PULMONARY NODULES ARE AS FOLLOWS:
        2 mm nodule along the right major fissure (3:37), stable.
        3 mm nodule within the right middle lobe (3:43), stable.
        5 mm nodule medially within the superior segment of the right
        lower lobe (3:43), previously 4 mm.
        5 mm left lower lobe subpleural (3:51), previously measured 4 mm.
        5 mm left lower lobe subpleural (3:59), previously measured 3 mm.
        2 mm right lower lobe (3:59), not previously seen.
        1 mm left lower lobe (3:68), stable.
        Left lower lobe calcified granuloma (3:71), stable.
        6 mm right lower lobe (3:72), stable.
        There is no pleural effusion or pleural thickening.
        The thyroid gland is unremarkable. There are no enlarged
        mediastinal, hilar, or axillary lymph nodes. The heart is normal
        in size. There are coronary artery atherosclerotic
        calcifications. The aorta and main pulmonary artery are normal in
        caliber. There is atherosclerotic calcification of the aortic
        arch and descending thoracic aorta. There is a small hiatal
        hernia.
        The breast parenchyma is unremarkable.
        The visualized structures of the upper abdomen are unremarkable.
        There is mild dextroscoliosis of the thoracic spine. There is a
        moderate T10 compression fracture. There are multilevel
        degenerative changes of the thoracic spine.
